moves.1. d3: This not an important game - but I leave you with a position where you have to find the next move - it is an interesting tactic!
moves.3. g3: He opts for a Modern Defence Reversed.
moves.4... f6: Preparing Be6, - I don't want it hit with Ng5.
moves.5. b3: This is passive - he needs to castle and then hit my centre.
moves.7. O-O: Natural - but rather falling in with my plans.
moves.7... Bc5:
Part of the standard attacking formation - see comparisons with the Yugoslav Attack against the Sicilian Dragon.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sicilian_Defence,_Dragon_Variation,_Yugoslav_Attack,_9.Bc4
moves.8. Re1: So that if I play Bh3 he can retreat his bishop.
moves.11... Bxd5: As his Nb1 is committed to d2, I can play this - otherwise I would have taken back with the knight - although maybe this is a mistake too, as he could now have play Ne4, attacking Bc5 and f6, forcing me to play Bd5xNe4.
moves.12. a3: White correctly starts queen-side operations - although maybe Ne4 was better.
moves.12... Ng6: Now Ne4 can be met with Be7.
moves.14. Nc4: He attacks my bishop - I can't prevent the exchange, but so what, I am attacking him on the king-side.
moves.16. Qa4: Threatening a check on a8. It doesn't do that much, but I decide on balance to prevent it with....
moves.17. e4: Perhaps stopping g5-g4 and the exchange of white squared bishops, but leaving his d pawn backwards on a semi-open file.
moves.18. Red1: Hoping to get in d3-d4 presumably.
moves.19. Bh1:
OK find black's next move?

Thank you for reading. Please rate this annotation on the star system and leave a comment or two to let me know how I am doing. until next time dear reader!
